Athletes May Play Where Toxic Fires Burned

The PJP Landfill in Jersey City may be transformed from a field of fire into a field of dreams. There has been talk recently of converting the 87-acre toxic dump into a recreational area, with fields for softball, cricket and football and a paved track.
A group of property owners, chemical companies and city officials who want to "make something good out of a bad situation" are leading the effort, said Alan Ashkinaze, a lawyer for the city.
From 1970 to 1985, fire raged continuously at the site, under the Pulaski Skyway. The flames were finally doused and the area partly cleaned up under the Federal Superfund program.

The final cleanup is the responsibility of 34 groups named in a 1982 lawsuit filed by the state and the Department of Environmental Protection; they include Exxon, General Motors, Sherwin-Williams and and Pfizer. Most of the land, now vacant, is owned by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark. Honk if You Love Wildlife Plates

Motorists willing to spend $50 to display their support for wildlife on their license plates contributed $725,000 to conservation programs last year, according to the Department of Environmental Protection. The "Conserve Wildlife" specialty plates, first issued in January 1994, pay for endangered and non-game species research and management.

There are signs that sales may be slowing this year. One reason could be that the wildlife plates are somewhat hard to come by: they are available only through the D.E.P. (by calling [ 800 ] WPLATES), not at offices of the Department of Motor Vehicles. Another could be the vast array of specialty plates now available. Admirers of flora and fauna can also choose from the shore protection plate (with a lighthouse; 38,786 sold last year) and the animal welfare plate (with a puppy, kitten and paw prints; 11,505 sold). In all, the D.M.V. issues 76 specialty plates, for everyone from combat infantrymen to Notre Dame alumni.

"If you make an 'I support the Olympics' plate and an 'I Support the Delaware River Water Gap' plate, how much can it be spread around?" said Bob Thompson, a D.M.V. spokesman. Inmates on the Beach For Shoreline Cleanup
Despite a major budget cut and the death of its founder last year, a program that puts prison inmates to work cleaning up the shoreline has hit the beach.

Under the program, inmates in work details of 16 to 20 men remove trash from beaches and waterways. It was created in 1989 by Michael Salvatore, a former special assistant for the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Corrections, a year after many beaches were closed when medical waste and trash floated ashore.
The program appeared headed for trouble last year, when the Legislature halved its $1 million budget. Then Mr. Salvatore died in September.

Nevertheless, inmates have been at work nearly all winter, planting 270,000 dune grass plugs to stop beach erosion, said Patricia Mulcahy, a spokeswoman for the Department of Corrections. A Radiator System To Reduce Smog

The Engelhard Corporation of Iselin has devised a system for cars that could reduce the levels of ozone and carbon monoxide. The system, called PremAir, destroys ozone (the main component of smog) and carbon monoxide already in the air through a clean air catalyst process. It would complement catalytic converters in automobiles, which destroy pollutants before they are released.

The system uses platinum and involves placing a catalytic coating on radiators and air-conditioning condensers. As air passes over them, they convert ozone into oxygen and carbon monoxide into carbon dioxide.
Engelhard is working with the Ford Motor Company (its biggest customer) to develop the technology, which could add $5oo to $1,000 to the price of a car. DAVID W. CHEN
